--- title: Cloud-native integration deployment 300-level live demo description: Cloud-native integration deployment 300-level live demo tabs: [ 'Demo preparation', 'Demo script'] --- export const Title = () => ( Cloud-native integration deployment
300-level live demo ); ![Dent Deletion banner](./images/cloud-native-integration-300-prep-banner.jpg) ### **NOTE**: August 9, 2022. There are currently issues with this demo’s environment. This note will be updated daily until the environment is back up. | DEMO OVERVIEW | | | :--- | :--- | | **Scenario overview** | Automate integration deployment using a cloud native approach to achieve greater productivity and simplified operations. Use an insurance quote aggregator scenario to demonstrate how the deployment of a complex integration solution can be automated using a pipeline. This demo also shows how container-based platforms enable operational consistency and automation across those capabilities, simplifying administration of an environment. | | **Demo products** | Cloud Pak for Integration | | **Demo capabilities** | Pipeline deployment; Container scalability and availability | | **Demo intro slides** | Download the Introduction and Overview slides here. This is a short deck of customer-facing slides that sets the context for the demo. | | **Demo script** | A complete demo script is on the second tab above. You can download a printer-ready PDF of the demo script here.

This demo script has multiple tasks that each have multiple steps. In each step, you have the details about what you need to do (**Actions**), what you can say while delivering this demo step (**Narration**), and what diagrams and screenshots you will see.

This demo script is a suggestion, and you are welcome to customize based in your sales opportunity. Most importantly, practice this demo in advance. If the demo seems easy for you to execute, the customer will focus on the content. If it seems difficult for you to execute, the customer will focus on your delivery. | | **Demo downloads** | Automating deployment of multi-style integrations pptx | | **Required versions** | Cloud Pak for Integration | | **How to get support** | Contact #itz-techzone-support or techzone.help@ibm.com regarding issues with reserving and provisioning TechZone environments.

Contact #platinumdemos-automation-support regarding issues with setting up and running this demo use case. | ## **DEMO INSTALLATION AND SETUP**
1 - Provision a Cloud Pak for Integration environment
Install Cloud Pak for Integration, or provision a ROKS environment. To reserve your ROKS instance, follow these steps:

1. To reserve a preinstalled Cloud Pak for Integration (CP4I) ROKS 4.6 cluster on Red Hat OpenShift, go here and complete the form. If you do not have a sales opportunity, select the purpose **Practice / Self-Education**.
2. You will receive a confirmation email confirming the instance is provisioning.

3. In approximately 30 minutes, you will receive a second email indicating the environment is provisioned. This email includes environment access information.

You are now ready to install Cloud Pak for Integration.

If you have issues connecting to your instance, contact #itz-techzone-support.
**[Go to top](#top)**
2 - Install Cloud Pak for Integration on ROKS cluster
1. Click here to install Cloud Pak for Integration. This link takes you to an IBM Cloud page. Log in with your personal IBM credentials.

Confirm you are using the **ITZ** account using the box in the upper right-hand corner of the intallation configuration page.


2. Ensure the product version is **2021.4.1-2**.


3. Scroll down the page to the **Select your cluster** section. From the list, select the Redhat Openshift Cluster you just created (1). Click **Add project** (2).


4. Name the **Project** cp4i (1). Click **Add** (2).


5. Scroll down to the **Set the deployment values** section. Toggle the **Use an existing secret?** option to **no** and define a new password. The new password needs to be 32-characters, using only letters and numbers. You will need this password in step 12.
NOTE: Currently, password validation is not enforced on this page. If you proceed with an invalid password you will be able to start the installation, but it will fail when you try to use it later. There is no way to recover from this error other than provisioning a new cluster.
6. Scroll down to **Parameters with default values**. Click the collapsible section to open them. First, we will select the appropriate parameter for this specific demo by setting the "drivewayDentDeletionDemo" field as 'true'. All other fields are left as 'false'.
| FIELD | ACTION | | ------ | ------- | | **cognitiveCarRepairDemo:** | Set to ‘false’ | | **drivewayDentDeletionDemo:** | Set to ‘true’ | | **eventEnabledInsuranceDemo:** | Set to ‘false’ | | **mappingAssistDemo:** | Set to ‘false’ | | **weatherChatbotDemo:** | Set to ‘false’ |

7. Continue to change the default values parameters using the table below.
If you do have an SMTP email server and accounts that you can use, you may sign up for a free Mailtrap.io account. Mailtrap.io is a free cloud service that mimics an SMTP server. It is used for development/demonstration purposes only.
| FIELD | ACTION | | ------ | ------- | | **demoAPICMailServerHost:** (1)| If you’re using mailtrap, leave this smtp.mailtrap.io. | | **demoAPICMailServerPort:** (2)| If you’re using mailtrap, leave this as 2525. | | **demoAPICEmailAddress:** (3)| If you’re using mailtrap, you can use any email address.
The dummy address ’apicadmin@example.com’ is recommended. If you’re using your own mail server, use an email address that you can receive and read. | | **demoAPICMialServerUsername:** (4)| Set this to your SMTP mailtrap username. This is different from your mailtrap login username and can be found by using these [instructions](https://help.mailtrap.io/article/5-smtp-integration). | | **demoAPICMailServerPassword:** (5)| Set this to your SMTP mailtrap password. This is different from your mailtrap login password and can be found by using these [instructions](https://help.mailtrap.io/article/5-smtp-integration). |

8. Accept the license agreement and click **Install** to install Cloud Pak for Integration. The installation will take up to 90 minutes.


9. You can view the progress in the Schematics progress bar or check the details in view log.


10. When the status is **Active**, you will be able to access Cloud Pak for Integration Platform Navigator. Select **Offering Dashboard** on the upper right corner of the page.


11. You will need Cloud Pak for Integration open for the demo, so copy and save this URL.
12. On the log in page, select the authentication type **IBM provided credentials (admin only)**.


13. Log in using the Username “admin” and the 32-character Password that you created in step 5.


14. Click **Integration instances**.


15. The parts of the Cloud Pak (API Connect, App Connect Designer, App Connect Dashboard and Asset Repository) will display here. Additional instances for any of the integration capabilities can be created by selecting **Create capability**.


You have successfully completed cluster provisioning, installation of Cloud Pak for Integration, and deployment of API Connect and App Connect. You are ready to proceed.
**[Go to top](#top)**
3 - Fork the GitHub repository
This demo uses a Tekton pipeline to build images and deploy them for four App Connect integration servers and one MQ server. Now we need to fork the GitHub repository with the demo assets, including the script to create the pipeline.
1. Open a browser and navigate to the cp4i-deployment-samples Github page.

2. Log in with your personal GitHub account. If you need a personal GitHub account, create one here.
3. Click **Fork**. 


4. Verify that you are using **Owner** (1) you intended. Click **Create fork** (2).


5. The **cp4i-deployment-samples** folder was forked the owner specified. Take note of the URL, it is required to complete section 5 of this preparation.
**[Go to top](#top)**
4 - Clone the GitHub repository to your machine
NOTE: To copy the repo you will need to have the Git CLI on your machine. If you don’t have it, follow the installation steps described in this page, based in your operating system.
1. On the forked repo, click **Code** (1). Click the icon to copy the URL (2).


2. Open your terminal window and execute this command:
``` git clone ```
NOTE: Do not copy the opening or closing arrows in the command. For example, the command should look like: git clone https://github.com/ibmryan/cp4i-deployment-samples.git
3. Open the cp4i-deployment-samples folder with this command:
``` cd cp4i-deployment-samples ```
4. You should now see a folder and multiple files. To be able to execute our script files, change the file permission with this command:
``` chmod 755 * ```
**[Go to top](#top)**
5 - Access your ROKS cluster and install the command line tool
In this section, you access your ROKS cluster and install the OpenShift command line tool. If you already have the command line tool, you can proceed to **6 - Access your ROKS cluster using CLI**.
1. Open My reservations in **IBM Technology Zone**.
2. Select your **CP4I ROKS** cluster.


3. Click **Open your Managed OpenShift (ROKS) environment**.


4. Click **OpenShift web console**.


5. On the web console page, click **?** (1), and select **Command line tools** (2). 


6. Follow the links to install the **OpenShift Command Line Interface** (CLI) for your Operating System. 


**[Go to top](#top)**
6 - Access your ROKS cluster using CLI
1. Log into your OpenShift cluster using CLI. From the dropdown menu in the upper right of the page, under your **username** (1), click **Copy login command** (2).


2. Click **Display Token**.


3. Copy the **login** command.


4. Open your terminal window and paste the **login command** to access your OpenShift cluster.


**[Go to top](#top)**
7 - Set up the parameters to install the pipeline
We need to set up pipeline triggers by linking the GitHub repository to OpenShift pipelines. Once this is done, when you commit a change to GitHub, your OpenShift pipeline runs automatically.
1. Set the namespace to be the correct namespace. It should be **cp4i**. On your terminal window, run this command:
``` export NAMESPACE=cp4i ```
2. Set the GitHub branch to **main** so the script knows which version of the GitHub artifacts to use.
``` export BRANCH=main ```
3. Set the GitHub repository to use as the URL of your forked repository (made in step 1).


In this example, the URL is https://github.com/rosorio/cp4i-deployment-samples.git.
``` export FORKED_REPO=https://github.com//cp4i-deployment-samples.git ```
**[Go to top](#top)**
8 - Create the pipeline
Follow these steps to create the pipeline on the OpenShift pipeline page. 
1. Open the **cp4i-deployment-samples folder**.

cd cp4i-deployment-samples, then open the **DrivewayDentDeletion/Operators folder**.

cd DrivewayDentDeletion/Operators

2. Create the pipeline by running this command.

./cicd-apply-test-apic-pipeline.sh -n $NAMESPACE -r $FORKED_REPO -b $BRANCH

3. In the terminal output, scroll to find the **Webhook route** URL. Copy and save the URL, as shown in this screenshot. It will be require to complete step 4.1.4 of the demo.


4. Return to the OpenShift console. On the left menu, open **Pipelines**, then **Pipelines** to see what has been added.

5. On the **Project combo box** (1), select **cp4i** (2).

6. Validate there is a pipeline.

**[Go to top](#top)**
9 - Download the BAR file
In this section, you download a BAR (broker archive) file to be used during the demo. 
1. Open this URL in your browser.
2. Click the **Download** button. 


You are ready to present the demo.
**[Go to top](#top)**
## **PREPARE TO GIVE THE DEMO**
Open these resources before starting demonstration
**1 - Cloud Pak for Integration**
1. Open a browser window, then paste and go to the CP4I URL you copied and saved from section **2.9 (Install Cloud Pak for Integration on ROKS cluster)** above. Log in using the Username “admin” and the 32-character Password that was created in step 2.5.
**2 - GitHub forked page**
1. Open a browser window, then paste and go to the Github URL to the **cp4i-deployment-samples folder** that you copied in section **3.5 (Fork the GitHub repository)** above.
**3 - OpenShift **
1. Open My reservations.
2. Select your **CP4I ROKS** cluster.

3. Click **Open your Managed OpenShift (ROKS) environment**.

**[Go to top](#top)**
Click [here](/300-integration-cloud-native-integration/demo-script) to go to the **Demo script** on the next tab.
